node.text: How do unrealistic expectations harm our relationships? Join the exploration on @sexwithemily’s podcast as I talk about exercises that help develop an embodied sense of sexuality, as well as my new game.

node.text:
As I travel this week, I was inspired by a beautiful @TED Talk from @taiye.entirely that encourages us to ask not where you are from but where you are local, and that resonated with me. Where we're from can be quite a limiting descriptor, whereas where we are local tells a fascinating story about where we feel at home, with whom we form our relationships, what rituals and cultural customs we hold dear and what restrictions dictate how we move through these places. 

Through the lens of this last year, we may have been "at home" but perhaps we didn't feel at home, as we were disconnected from the experiences that make a place feel familiar and resonant. So, I'm curious, not where you're from, but where do you feel local? 
To listen to Taiye's exploration of this topic, visit the link in my bio.

node.text:
I’m hearing a lot about burnout lately, from friends, clients and colleagues. It seems that many of us are in need of a break right now. 

As I take a moment of vacation, I am reminding myself (and all of you) that a break is freedom from any “must do”. It’s not a chance to do all the things I’ve been neglecting but an opportunity to just be, releasing the need to produce and optimize, and instead allowing life to happen around me. By relinquishing agency, I can truly relax.

node.text:
We’re asking ourselves many questions right now as we rediscover how we relate to one another. Should we gather? Is it safe? And once we’re together, what can we ask? What can we tell? So much has happened in the last 18 months, that we long to deepen our conversations past the surface. 

For more on reconnection, listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on his podcast On Purpose.

It's not a permanent state of enthusiasm. Love is something that you actively cultivate.

Listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on this week's episode of On Purpose wherever you get your podcasts.

node.text:
This couple came to talk about the deep conflict and the secrets that they both carry surrounding their work. One person can't talk about what she does and one person can't talk about the fact that he no longer wants to do what he does.

Season 2 of #HowsWorkPodcast is now available on all platforms.

🎧 Listen to If I Quit, What Will People Say? on Spotify or wherever you get your podcasts.

For show notes and transcripts, visit estherperel.com/podcast

node.text:
This is the story of #WhereShouldWeBegin, the game. 

The pandemic left us missing intimacy and play, so I created a game to help us rediscover both. Designed for partners, dates, or friends, Where Should We Begin? is many games at once. I have played it with my team, my family, and my oldest friends. And each time we have discovered something new about each other.

To preorder the game, visit estherperel.com/thegame or click the link in my profile bio.

For the time being, we are only shipping to the United States. We will ship internationally in the future — stay tuned.

node.text:
@rachelbotsman defines trust as “a confident engagement with the unknown.”

In relationships, trust isn’t a promise to never hurt each other. It’s the risk that we will hurt each other and the confidence that, if we do, we will come together to heal. We will support one another. We will be kind. We will have each others’ backs. And it’s not just something that happens because we’ve decided to be together, or to move in, or to say “I do.”

Cultivating that level of trust requires millions of micro-risks that show us we’re not foolish for being confident in our relationship. It requires taking risks together that show us our partner isn’t the same as the people from our past who hurt us. Most importantly, trust requires taking risks together that help us grow into better partners for each other.

Here are five small micro-risks to help build trust in your relationships:

Go outside and say hello to the strangers you pass.
Compliment someone on something specific.
Call your friend who’s been feeling blue and leave voicemails even if know they won’t respond.
Tell your partner you’re taking them on a date even if you know they’d rather watch TV.
Tell your partner something about yourself that they don’t know. (This is one of my favorite exercises in therapy.)

This clip is an excerpt from this week's #LettersFromEsther workshop: Risk-Taking and Trust. To watch the full video, visit my YouTube channel: YouTube.com/estherperel/live

node.text:
On May 20th, we will begin #7DaysForPlay. Sign up to receive daily small, sensual, playful exercises to help you practice slowing down and connecting to your erotic self.

Register for this free challenge at bitly.com/7daysforplay or by clicking the link in my profile bio.

If you know someone who may wish to join us, send them this video or tag them in the comments below.

(There is a version for people who are in a relationship and for those who are solo. I suggest choosing the option that corresponds to your relationship status, even if you won't be doing this with your partner.)

node.text:
Foreplay doesn’t need to be something that diminishes as we get older, it’s an energy that deepens as we grow. Foreplay is for play.

On the subject of anticipation, something playful is coming soon. Join me for my upcoming free audio series, The Art of Foreplay: bitly.com/7daysforplay.

#7DaysForPlay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text:
Where Should We Begin is back in stock for pre-order after selling out of our first release!

I created the game to help you bring playfulness and story-telling to your gatherings. Think of it as an opportunity to restore or build relationships with ourselves and each other, especially as we emerge from social isolation. 

Inspired by my own conversations with my closest friends, colleagues, family, and clients, the game unlocks the storyteller within and reveals just how much more there is to know about those we thought we knew. Follow the link in my bio or preorder at https://www.estherperel.com/where-should-we-begin-the-game. 

Let’s begin! I’d love to hear what stories you’re unlocking with the game, your favorite questions, and most memorable moments. Share in the comments below!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sessions Live 2021 November 6, 13, and 20 The Great Adaptation How can we stay grounded when the ground is moving? BROUGHT TO YOU BY SESSIONS WITH ESTHER PEREL'.

node.text:
Eighteen months of prolonged uncertainty has been stressful to therapists and clients alike. We keep asking ourselves: how can we stay grounded when the ground is moving? How do we provide emotional support when we ourselves are depleted? How do we balance the needs of our clients when our own families need us too?

To ensure that we can continue to do our work well, it is crucial that we—as therapists, coaches, and professionals working with relationships and well being—are supporting and resourcing each other.

I am excited to announce that my 5th annual Sessions Live conference will tackle these subjects head on. On our virtual platform, over the first three Saturdays in November, we will examine the goals, role, and limitations of therapy in a time of overlapping large scale crises. Each day will focus on how adaptability, mass mutual reliance, and collective resilience are crucial to meeting this moment.

Early bird tickets are available now until 9/27. Secure your spot today by visiting https://sessions.estherperel.com/sessions-live-2021 or the link in my bio. The conference is live online, however all ticket holders will receive access to the archived videos at the end of programming each day.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, sitting and indoor.

node.text:
Today, I am inspired by my friends at @labshul, as well as @amichailaulavie and @revdrdrock as the new Shmita year has begun, denoting a time of rest, recollection, self-care and social reform.

Also known as the Sabbatical Year in Jewish tradition, the Shmita occurs every seven years, and literally translates to “release” or “let go” originally based on a historical pause for agricultural economies as mandated by legal codes in Israel. Farmers of Biblical times were directly ordered to rest during this time, debts were released, and focus turned to restoration and renewal. 

As the world begins to recover from the widespread effects of the pandemic and adapt to the new landscape, I am finding the timing quite appropriate for a Shmita year as we reconcile a time of chaos and unrest. Could the Hebrew calendar be offering us inspiration for our own renewal and regeneration? For the reunion of our world and its people? 

What if “rest” was not only encouraged - but required? 
What if working to release our past debts, anxieties, grudges and brokenness was truly held as essential? 

We are provided seasonal and cyclical opportunities to rest, recover, and restart anew - Shmita is just one such opportunity. If it calls to you, I encourage you to learn more, approach with curiosity, and see what inspires you in the tradition. As we all turn to focus on the global recovery that is and will continue to occur in the coming months, we can become collaborators in a wider system of healing and cooperation.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Question 1 How has art, music, or nature helped you in challenging times?'.

node.text:
For the last week, we’ve been speaking about Eroticism in Hard Times, how this life force keeps us connected to our sense of humanity, hope, and pleasure — especially when we are in pain. Today, let’s turn the lens on you. In times of despair and grief, where have you found hope? How has art, music, or nature helped you in challenging moments? In what ways have you revived the erotic in the last year?

As we prepare for tomorrow’s workshop on YouTube and Facebook at 3pm EST, we will be exploring these questions, your answers, and practices for engaging eroticism when it may feel particularly challenging.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 13, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
From the pandemic to climate crisis to crimes against humanity, severe burnout, and more, we are living through collective trauma. Our impulse may be to shut down, numb ourselves with substances, disconnect, sleep forever, wallow in the 24 hour news cycle, or stuff every free moment with social media to avoid difficult thoughts and feelings. But today, I invite you to try something different. I invite you to embrace your Erotic self—the parts of your existence which make you feel alive, as has been described by Audre Lorde, in the Zohar, and by many others. You may think that talking about Eroticism at a time like this is hubris, but I think it is essential.

Read more in this month's newsletter through the link in bio, and stay tuned for Wednesday’s workshop at 3pm EST on inviting eroticism into challenging moments.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel in New York City with @gampelabigail, and @jacksaulofficial. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
In the 90’s, @jacksaulofficial founded the International Trauma Studies program, and we both channeled that work into the arts through Theater Arts against Political Violence - a project that focused on testimonials and witnessing.

After 9/11 devastated New York, we created a theater piece to capture the voices of those New Yorkers who were not being heard - members of the local community who were deeply affected by 9/11 emotionally and psychologically. The conversation in NY had been so focused on the lives we lost, that we were inadvertently ignoring the experiences of the living. 

Led by Jack and Director Abigail Gampel, we conducted 4-months of interviews. Focusing on what resonated most deeply from each story, we found through lines and central themes, translating them into scenes, monologues, interviews and deeply human vignettes that comprised an overarching narrative, a tapestry of heartache and grief felt by an entire community. 

The play “Everything is Back to Normal in New York City” was an ironic response to Mayor Giuliani’s statement. Clearly, the trauma of the surrounding community and individual experiences had just begun and even intensified as the shock dissolved into grief, anxiety and depression. 

I was in the neighborhood on 9/11, as my two boys were at PS 234, a school just blocks away from the Twin Towers - a story I tell in the play as I wrestle with a complex array of emotion, bordering on dark humor. That day, Jack and I were both professionals and parents, called to support our clients and community while also having a deeply emotional and turbulent experience ourselves.

Today, 20 years later, as we honor the lives lost in 9/11 and pay tribute to them, we also find ourselves in a global pandemic, in a time of constant conflict and after years of ongoing war in Irak and Afghanistan. And the through lines of collective trauma and shared international grief have never been more relevant, reminding us of the importance of unification and community healing. Living in the tightly knit fabric of New York City since 2001 reminds me daily of the resilience and restoration that can be accomplished when we take care of and support each other.

node.text:
Let’s play! 
This week, I joined @ericachidi on the @goop podcast to talk about why “play” is important to cultivate, especially as adults, and how the stories we share can deeply connect us to one another. We discuss Where Should We Begin, my new card game designed to introduce playfulness and storytelling into your next date, dinner party, or intimate get together. Listen through the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be a cartoon of one or more people and text that says '刀 Dating Advice for Turning a Spark into a Flame'.

node.text: Modern dating, especially in the era of apps and online connection, has become a bit stale. I hear so many friends, clients, and colleagues talk about the challenges of dating today - between the lunch date, the dinner date, the coffee date, and all of their implied expectations, the structure has become so confining and often lacks imagination. To me, the three most important ingredients of a good date are creativity, engagement, and surprise. These elements play together to ignite a spark and fuel the small flame of a new relationship. Swipe through for dating advice, and visit my blog on the topic in the link in my bio and at estherperel.com/blog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be a cartoon of one or more people and text that says '刀 Dating Advice for Turning a Spark into a Flame'.

Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Context is Key Dinner and drinks are great, but playing tennis or a board game can show us how they win and lose (which tells a lot about a person). But if you really want to get to know somebody, invite them and their friends to a party with your friends.'.

Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It's an Education, not an Interview We seek to maximize the efficiency of our dates, to get through them so we can skip right to the cost-benefit analysis, but just because someone doesn't check all of our boxes, doesn't mean they don't have something to offer that we've never thought of before. Be open to experiencing a person, not evaluating.'.

Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'To Seduce and To Be Seduced Desire needs mystery and, in the beginning, everything is mysterious. Seduction is a way to explore the boundaries of each others' worlds, histories, fantasies, and desires-and that type of play is an education unto itself.'.

Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Connection or No Connection, Follow Up Enjoyed the first date? Say so. Didn't enjoy the first date? Say so. Ultimately, there is nothing you can say that makes rejecting someone or being rejected any easier, but you can communicate in a way that doesn't make the other person feel devalued or dismissed.'.
Photo by Esther Perel on September 08, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
I met with @theskimm and discussed how to create meaningful relationships with our coworkers, and the reasons our interpersonal skills are just as important as any of the skills we list on our resume.
Find the link in my bio to listen to the whole episode: https://www.theskimm.com/money/9-to-5ish-esther-perel-4z0g6sher38FSoxO4mICCh

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
I frequently explain how in modern culture, we turn to one person, our partner, to provide what an entire village once did: a sense of grounding, meaning, and continuity. But we shouldn’t forget the importance of the village: how we build it and how we maintain it.

Friendships have carried me through so many things, including love and loss. They've sheltered me from many storms and remain a part of my life that I enjoy expanding and nurturing. So this season on my podcast, “Where Should We Begin,” we will pursue new conversations about friendship. 

If you are interested in being on the podcast, please let us know. These conversations could involve someone you have lost touch with, the friend you wish would forgive you, or the one you wish to let go of. If you are feeling stuck and think a session with me could help you two and you are interested in being on the podcast please tell me your story follow the link in my bio or apply here: https://whereshouldwebegin.estherperel.com/apply

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says '" Seduction is a way to explore each others' worlds histories, fantasies, and desires and that type of play is an education in itself. Esther Perel'.

node.text:
Seduction is a way to explore each others' worlds, histories, fantasies, and desires—and that type of play is an education unto itself. 

In the early stages of dating, we hope to discover more about the other person through intense emotional and physical connection. This relies on play. True seduction is a slow process, but it is accelerated by the feeling of newness between two people. Newness brings excitement and room for mystery—and that mystery allows for play. 

In our blog “Dating Advice for Turning a Spark into a Flame,” we discuss tools for making a first date successful, including the art of seduction. Follow the link in my bio!
